I certainly found it a very worthwhile exercise and I am pleased that I now have a better understanding of the needs of the ageing population in my own electorate. I have had further contact with the disabled in my own electorate, as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs, Home but not alone, which has been tabled in this place this week. I must say at the very outset that this review is certainly due, as no review into this program has been conducted since it began in 1986. The report is certainly long overdue in that respect. This program is well worth while.

PARA.TAB: It should always be remembered that the area of home and community care is incredibly diverse and that there are different situations calling for different solutions. There is no hard and fast recipe for the delivery of the best home and community care, but this report does indicate some very helpful solutions to some very complex problems. The report makes over 80 recommendations, all of which will be helpful for improved delivery of home and community care.

One of the most important and constructive aspects of this report is its recommendations on post-acute and palliative care. The evidence that we collected certainly seemed to suggest that more and more home and community care resources are being used for post-acute cases. It does seem that many in the HACC community believe that increasing early discharge from hospitals is driven largely by the budgetary interests of the hospital rather than the individual interests of the patient.

Because of the potential for problems in this area, this report recognises that the same level of care needs to be continued after HACC recipients have been discharged from hospital. The report recommends that the same care providers be maintained for the HACC recipients after they leave hospital, that is, immediately they leave hospital.

Numerous examples were given to the committee throughout our deliberations of patients who, when discharged from hospital, were given a clear indication that they were not the responsibility of the hospital or the health sector any more. This is the reason the committee felt it was essential to ensure that the care at home for the HACC client be recognised as part of the ongoing treatment for the acute episode, with no less medical responsibility than the care conducted in the hospital.

The committee believes that the best way to address the problems in this area is to change the financial responsibility for palliative and post-acute care from community services, which currently deals with it, back to health. This will provide a one-stop shop. It will remove the cumbersome duality of dealing with both the health system and the community services program. It will remove the problem of the left hand not knowing what the right hand is doing when dealing with the same patient. It will also—and most importantly—remove the `It's not my responsibility; it's theirs' attitude, which seems to have dogged the delivery of a coordinated and sustained service in the hospital and after discharge. The recommendations of this report provide a structure which is far more simple and logical than the one which exists at the moment.

Regionalisation is an aspect of the report which is logical and certainly well needed. HACC service deliverers at the moment range from incredibly small community services to some organisations which run services throughout the entire state. They are very diverse in their size and their operations.

The inquiry bore out the fact that the regional boundaries which were used by state and Commonwealth departments were constructed in an arbitrary manner and were essentially a bit of a shambles. The locality distinctions that exist between health, aged services and HACC mean that a lot of the data collected, in holistic terms, was meaningless.

There is a definite trend in the state sphere for health services to be regionalised, giving to each region an individual budget and a greater deal of say over how that budget is used. For instance, my state of Tasmania is divided into three regions for the purposes of health service delivery: the north, the north-west and south. They all have their own pool of funds and all have to provide a certain level of service. How they use these funds and deliver that service is fundamentally up to them.

Because of health regionalisation and the fact that the boundaries of health assets and transport systems are regional, it is totally logical that home and community care be dovetailed to reflect that regional structure. This would mean that the Commonwealth boundaries for the provision of HACC and other services such as aged care and nursing home and hostel services would mirror regional health structures. This is a logical and very simple step.

There may have to be some tinkering around to enable compatibility with census collection districts but, essentially, it will mean a move from arbitrary boundaries, which are not reflected by the provision of services which should go hand in hand, to real boundaries on a geographic basis.

Obviously, transferring such a service to a regional entity must mean that a regional budget holder is established alongside a regional review and complaints mechanism and fully functional regional forums. The emphasis that we heard on this through the hearings was that those regional forums need to be fully functional. The report I speak to today makes definite provision for this.

The holder of the regional budget could take a number of forms. It could be a joint Commonwealth-state group, wholly and solely a state group, or a community body which has been appointed by the two tiers of government. One factor remains paramount in the establishment of this process: whatever structure the regional budget holder takes, it must be totally autonomous and free of any interference by state or federal governments. The key point of this recommendation is that none of the normal home and community care services would be funded on a state-wide basis. This would make the service free of state government interference. Autonomy over HACC funding would be given to regions. This would allow those individual regions to develop their own methods of service delivery which were the most efficient for that area.

The most important and far-reaching recommendation of this report, however, is the establishment of the regional community assessment agency. This agency would be responsible for a region, with the state health regions that are already in existence as the starting point. This agency would become the only access point to home and community care services and would take over all the current functions of the aged care assessment team. The central point of this recommendation is to avoid duplication of services by the agency having sole responsibility for the determination of where resources will go. It will also have the ability to use those resources most efficiently by being able to contract out its functions to other agencies. For example, the regional community assessment agency could choose to contract out its powers in a small town to a disability assessment group which already exists. This ability to contract out has a number of advantages. It will enable the use of more specialised staff such as interpreters on a needs basis. This will ensure cultural and language sensitivity as and where it is required.

This agency would use staff who are trained appropriately for the specific task that they will undertake. Work will not be conducted outside the specialty area of the individual. This agency will perform the incredibly important role of determining the needs of those being discharged from hospital who require home support. This goes to the central core of the problem of casemix and early discharge. The use of this specialist and expert agency to assess home support needs of individuals will certainly make sure that hospitals are not merely discharging their patients early to save a few bucks.

One of the areas of the report that I view as being very pleasing is the particular attention it pays to the needs of access to HACC by special needs groups. It recommends that a national policy be developed to provide access to HACC services for people from a non-English speaking background. It is well known that people from a non-English speaking background do not get their fair share of health services for one reason or another. This report will go some way towards addressing that.

I would like to thank my colleague opposite, the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), and other members of the committee for, firstly, the learning process that I actually went through with that committee and, secondly, for their support during our deliberations. I would also like to thank the reporting staff from Hansard and the secretarial staff that assisted us throughout our deliberations nationwide. It is a well worthwhile report. I believe it is one of the most excellent reports that I have seen during my time of interest in these areas. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure for me to rise for the first time in this second chamber. On Monday, the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) tabled a report entitled Home but not alone, which should become a landmark in providing community services to the people of Australia. This report follows a report over a decade ago entitled In a home or at home that was chaired by the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay). That report was the genesis of the home and community care program. It is certainly very timely that this far into the program we should be having a look at a review.

PARA.TAB: As shadow minister for community services, I congratulate the chairperson and the members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs who have produced this report. They have produced a report that is comprehensive in its scope, benefiting from extensive public consultations and hearings and producing recommendations that are both wide ranging and thoughtful.

This is a document that federal, state and territory governments would be foolish to ignore because collectively they have responsibility for the management of the home and community care program. The committee's report highlights many failings and shortcomings in the management and delivery of HACC, some of which I will consider in a moment. But let me say now that the existence of this program, and the goal of allowing as many as possible elderly and functionally disabled people to remain in their homes and in their communities, is not questioned by me or the coalition. The federal coalition supports this objective and, of course, six of the eight state and territory governments that deliver HACC services are coalition governments.

The committee's report makes it clear that there is overwhelming support for the HACC program and for its future. Minimising the need for residential care is a characteristic of a society which cherishes and values its members regardless of their age or their infirmity.

Indeed, HACC does have many success stories. Let me talk about the city of Box Hill, a municipality I represent in the federal parliament. It delivers a comprehensive home and community care service and it does it very well. Box Hill adopts a holistic approach to its services. For example, the city uses its own nursing staff to provide acute care in the home, along with the more traditional HACC program services. It complements the work of the Box Hill hospital and other acute care hospitals as in-patient stays become shorter. It has got a successful disability support program, and the key word of this program is `flexibility'. The city can react to consumer and care needs effectively and deliver services with the greatest possible efficiency and least financial cost. Jenny Nelson, the home and community care coordinator for the city of Box Hill, manages the city's home and community care services. She, her colleagues and the service providers and volunteers with whom she works are just some of the thousands of quiet heroes of the home and community care program.

But as the standing committee report demonstrates very conclusively, the current overall state of home and community care is not so healthy. Its effectiveness is greatly impeded by a whole range of factors, including a lack of clear objectives and no sharply defined picture of the types of consumers in the functionally disabled group it is meant to service. There is considerable duplication of functions between Commonwealth, state and local government, with the inevitable consequences for efficiency and quality of services to consumers. There is a lack of strategic planning and outcomes standards. Insufficient information and advice is available for consumers and carers, and the program is simply not coping with the stresses of the advances in acute care and reduced in-patient treatment.

I want to touch briefly on three of these points: duplication, the relationship between acute and community care and the recognition of carers. First of all, duplication of effort seems to be the most profound weakness in the home and community care program. This is a frustrating, but understandable, result of a program which involves Commonwealth, state and territory governments as full partners under the HACC agreement, and which also involves local governments such as the city of Box Hill in the delivery of services.

Put simply, there are too many cooks spoiling the HACC broth. The Commonwealth gets bogged down in the finer detail of who provides what services in given states beyond the broad strategic and financial management that one would expect. The states, which have the day-to-day program management responsibilities within their jurisdictions, find the Commonwealth guidelines and priorities mean that they do not have as much freedom to make the allocation decisions they would like, which they believe are most appropriate to the needs of their residents. Local governments, which provide about 20 per cent of HACC services, are not even recognised in HACC agreements except as part of a state's overall funding effort.

This can lead to confusion on the part of government and non-government service providers about just who they are responsible to in terms of provision of services, and to whom they are financially accountable for their funding, especially given the crucial importance of Commonwealth-state matching funding. What is more serious, however, is that such an overlay of bureaucracy and red tape diverts precious taxpayer resources from the consumers they are intended to benefit: the frail aged, the younger disabled and their carers.

A major theme of the committee's report is the need for a more strategic framework for the HACC program under which the Commonwealth, in consultation with the states and territories, provides a broad strategic direction and sets national program priorities. If this is allowed to happen, the states can get on with the job of providing high quality and well targeted home and community care. Perhaps then we will see the states and territories more likely to meet their matching funding obligations under the HACC agreement.

With things as they are now, it is not altogether surprising that there has been a growing tendency for at least some states and territories to underspend their commitments, leading to the withdrawal of federal funds. To put this in some perspective, ACOSS has estimated that, to the end of 1992-93, federal and state spending has fallen short of promised commitments by $150 million. That money would have bought a lot of needed services.

Such issues could have been taken up usefully in the context of the recent COAG meeting, but seem to have been lost in the impasse over the effects on the states of the Hilmer competition reforms. This, now, is a challenge for a federal government to take up. I hope this federal government takes it up but, if not, the following federal coalition government will take it up.

Something that took up much of the committee's time, and which featured in many of the submissions and public evidence it received, was the growing inability of HACC and other community based schemes to come to terms with the overwhelming pressure of clients requiring considerable post-acute care. This is something the Australian community needs to confront as the duration of in-patient treatment continues to decline, due to such obvious things as casemix funding and less obvious factors such as less invasive surgical techniques, advances in antibiotics and other medical and surgical advances.

The Australian Institute of Health calculates that between 1982-83 and 1991-92 the average duration in hospital dropped from 6.9 days to 5.0 days. That is a big drop. It is reasonable to suggest that the average stay would probably be less now. Critics of casemix funding will argue that this reflects the considerable disincentive effect of casemix treatment on the way hospitals approach their patients but, as the committee rightly points out, this trend to shorter hospital stays considerably predates the introduction of casemix. What it reflects more is society's rapid strides in medical technology and treatment, but it does not take away from the fact that discharged patients in the HACC client group still need to convalesce and are expected to convalesce at home.

In most cases, these people and their carers need priority access to home and community care services, often at the expense of other eligible people. While the statistics on the quantity of post-acute home and community care are imprecise, the anecdotal evidence gathered by the mid-term review of aged care, and now this committee, is a convincing indication of the growth in demand for such services.

However, the committee not only identifies the problem but comes up with some possible solutions, including making discharge planning an integral part of a hospital's care of its patients; the committee's proposed regional community assessment agency working with hospital and service providers to develop and purchase suitable post-acute care packages; and, where HACC services were provided prior to hospital admission, ensuring continuity of service provision wherever appropriate. The continuity of care from acute episodes to post-acute care is something to be encouraged, not ignored. These recommendations are some of the most positive to come out of the committee and they have my support.

Encouraging hospitals to become more committed to discharge planning and giving full recognition to the acute care experience is only part of a patient's healing process, and it is something I welcome as a medical practitioner. In the last couple of days I have consulted with several groups, including the Council on the Ageing and Aged Care Australia, which also welcome the committee's recommendations. State and federal ministers and policy makers should not dismiss these recommendations lightly.

A highly significant group of people whose needs and frustrations are brought out in this standing committee report are the carers of people with functional disabilities eligible for HACC assistance. By carers I mean the hardworking and loving parents, spouses, partners and other relatives and friends who give up some or all of their time and resources to care for someone close to them who cannot cope on his or her own. It is a term that has become rather blurred in recent years, particularly as governments apply it to a wide range of other people and service providers who professionally or voluntarily become involved in the caring process. I think that is an enormous pity.

The Carers Association of Australia told the committee that carers are fundamental to and represent the cornerstone of community care—a succinct statement, but one that is very true. It too often seems, however, that carers—who are included in the HACC agreement's defined target group for the home and community care program—are overlooked when it comes to delivering HACC services and in making decisions about a priority for assistance under the program. When the competition for scarce resources is most intense, a focus on those most frail is understandable but in some ways unfortunate. I believe that the standing committee's report reflects a growing community realisation of the value of these unpaid personal carers who, out of love or personal duty, perform a difficult and challenging role without which the community would be much the poorer. Translated into financial savings, their services have to be worth billions of dollars a year.

The committee's report makes clear that carers need to get a better deal under the HACC program in a range of areas such as actual hands-on assistance in their caring tasks; a better understanding of the services available for those that they are caring for and for themselves; a greater voice in how HACC services are planned and delivered; and, most importantly, reasonable access to at least some regular respite care from their highly intense responsibilities to allow them to carry on with those responsibilities.

The availability of respite care is overwhelmingly the greatest concern of carers and carer groups. Many of these carers are elderly husbands and wives who may not themselves be in the best of health. Other carers, often daughters, are younger but have the additional stress of raising families of their own, let alone the never-ending task of making ends meet.

When we talk of carers we risk taking them for granted. They are not a race of superhuman beings; they need support and love just as much as those for whom they care and, indeed, as much as anyone. The coalition believes that the contribution of carers to the wellbeing of Australian society should not only be recognised but should be tangibly and positively assisted. In government, we will be looking at ways of ensuring through HACC and other avenues that carers receive a fair deal from the community in return for their own commitment. Improving and expanding respite care and other support and information services for carers is a priority for us.

In the meantime, the committee has recommended that the Commonwealth, states and territories look at improving respite care delivery through greater research into the target group of carers, the service needs of carers and the extent to which carers can gain access to HACC services. That is a recommendation which I welcome. I also welcome the report's recognition of the invaluable role of the Carers Association of Australia and other voluntary and community sector organisations in supporting carers and keeping them informed of the assistance available.

In this regard, I note the report's general encouragement of a greater role for volunteers in the provision of home and community care. I can see in the provision of, particularly, short-term respite care and support services along the lines of community visitors in nursing homes that volunteers with basic skills, a little time and a lot of goodwill can play a role which will enrich themselves, those they help and the wider community.

This report, considered point by point, could fuel a debate in this chamber for far longer than we are going to talk about it today. I congratulate members of the committee. I know myself what is involved in producing a large report. This is an important area. HACC has made a big change to Australia and if these recommendations are adopted it can continue its work for the next century.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Firstly, I would like to say that I welcome the comments from the shadow minister for community services, senior citizens and aged care the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge). Obviously, I was aware that he was following the inquiry of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs and I think his contribution augurs well for the community debate that will now hopefully take place around this report, which is entitled Home but not alone. In my comments in the House previously I referred to some aspects of the report. I do not want to extend the debate too much in some of those areas, but there are two important issues I want to touch on, and perhaps explain in a bit more detail the committee's thinking behind some of its recommendations.

PARA.TAB: The first one of these is what we have called the regional community assessment agency. This to some people could seem to be a large and potentially monolithic organisation—and, if it were badly designed, badly structured, it could be. But, if one looks at what is occurring now and the kinds of problems that we have with the delivery and the administration of HACC, the fact that the providers of services are also the people who assess the need does pose a potential conflict of interest and it does potentially jaundice the function of that.

Secondly, there is the question of the capacity of many of the small providers to be sensitive to language and culture, so they can bring an interpreter into a household where the recipient is from a non-English speaking background, or their carer may be. In many cases the carer is forgotten in that context. Many of the smaller organisations just cannot handle that kind of need.

If we look at the collection of data and look at the shortfall of HACC, we have literally thousands of HACC waiting lists all over Australia. There is no way we can measure the shortfall or the shortcomings because every organisation has its own waiting list. People go from service to service to service to try to find some capacity, and in so many cases give up in frustration. We had evidence of what we called assistance stress, where people may be assessed four or five or six times for meals, for home modification, for home maintenance, for home care, home support, for personal care, for nursing care, all by different groups, all with a different service. They may have four or five or six different providers of services at different times, and those providers may be replaced from time to time. In that situation, for both the recipient and in many cases for the carer, that can be a very destabilising and dislocating experience.

The other aspect of the assessment process is the fact that we really need to focus on this question about continuity of care between hospitals and the community. The question about casemix that comes forward is: do people really trust the hospitals discharging early? The evidence is overwhelming that early discharge, appropriately handled and supported, is medically sound practice and is good for the community. One of the points I have been making is that there is not much golden staph in people's homes. People are less likely to get ill at home than they are in hospital. Their neighbours are nearby, their friends and families can visit whenever they like, so they are back into a network which is more comfortable, though they really need to be sure the services are there when they need them. But there is a level of concern—`Am I being discharged to save the hospital money or because it is good for my health?'—and, while ever that question mark is over it, the whole issue of casemix will be retarded in implementation, and the development of appropriate instruments of measurement, whether they are diagnostic related groups or some other form of unit cost, will be held up.

The concept that we have tried to tie together is the desperate need for a third party, an independent arbiter, who will be able to assess a patient and assess the home—not simply assess the patient's wound or surgery or rehabilitation needs but assess the patient's home in terms of its suitability, and assess the capacity of the carer, if he or she has one, on some objective basis. The prime concern of that assessment is for that person, not for the hospital and not for the health system. If one looks at trying to link post-acute care or the hospital experience with the at-home experience, clearly one wants to get that third-party arbitration, and the assessment agency would provide us with that scope.

It also means that over time we can establish as a country and as communities what we are short of: we can see what form of assessment is made of nursing home hours required and what is provided; we can assess what transport needs are not being met; we can establish accurate barometers and measurements of shortfall. Then governments, both state and federal, and even local, could respond to those, because those needs will be visible and professional. I find it somewhat irksome that a doctor can prescribe a blood test and it gets done, regardless of the cost; someone does not say there is no budget left for a blood test. But, if you want to prescribe some home nursing, that requires a budget; if there is no money you do not get it. It seems to me that that is fundamentally unfair.

This report does not go to the extent of saying that HACC should be an entitlement. It starts to prepare us for the potentiality of that. I think it is about time that governments faced up to this issue. We cannot keep on talking about the benefits of home and community care and ignore the financial responsibilities. With respect to the establishment of a common assessment group, I have said that these groups can be geographically distributed and electronically interconnected. That is pretty good jargon, I suppose, but it is trying to find the form of words to say that it does not need to be a single body in a single building.

It can be a whole series of organisations linked together—it is important that they be linked to the information—so that a person is assessed once and assessed professionally. The information would then be available to all aspects of the assessment group. Another issue is that a group can exist in a particular region, so that people in different towns are contactable. The point is that there would be one point of contact, but it would not necessarily be monolithic.

The assessment can also be contracted out by that group and not by somebody else. However, the methods to be used—the instruments of assessment—would be common. Regardless of whether the assessment was being done in a small town or a large town, it would be done on the same basis and the data collected would be available. Having one common group would mean that when a person from the common group goes to speak to someone who might need home delivered meals, that person can also check the house, the carer and the person receiving the meals. In that way, if there is some dementia, or there are some problems with the house, or the carer, that is picked up. The situation at the moment is that many of the services can only assess for their service and nothing else. That shortfall could be overcome with this. With a central database, the original assessment would always be available. If in the years ahead that person's health deteriorated, that original assessment would be available. We would then have a starting point and the deterioration could be understood and recognised.

Some people may see the assessment agency as potentially threatening but there is no reason why it should be. To try to counter that potential threat we have recommended that there be regional forums to discuss the assessments. This would mean that there would be some level of external accountability to make sure that the assessment agency is not seen as some secret body that has supreme power. Also, the assessments would be reviewable and they would be able to be appealed against. Regional forums would discuss the assessment instrument, so that there would be a community understanding of that.

I know there are other people who wish to speak on this debate and, in the time ahead, we may wish to return to this topic, so I hope it is listed for the Main Committee for subsequent days. The report is now available to the public and, as members get feedback from their constituencies, I am confident that there will be a need to list it again for discussion at some further stage. It may well be that this Main Committee may assist in the process of furthering the debate and furthering the understanding, as members bring forward the responses they are receiving. I think we are the first committee to bring a report here. I thank the Main Committee for that opportunity and I trust that we may return.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I have, as Opposition Whip in the Main Committee, spent more time in this facility than anyone else, it is the first time that I have taken the opportunity to speak on a particular matter that is before the parliament. I have chosen to speak on this matter because I represent what I think is statistically the oldest electorate in Australia, that is from my recollection of the last—

PARA.TAB: Mr Allan Morris interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The member suggests that someone with my lack of hair is perhaps a suitable representative, but that belies my age, I can assure you. Statistics from the 1990 or 1991 census revealed that the electorate of McPherson had the highest median age group of any electorate in Australia. Of course, that adds up when you consider that the area is probably the retirement capital of Australia. Many people come to the Gold Coast region to enjoy their retirement. It is a very suitable place for people to retire: it is congenial and there are many services available for aged people and, of course, the climate is ideal.

PARA.TAB: Even though we do have many people coming here to retire, that has been changing over time. An increasing number of families are now moving to the Gold Coast. Many of the new subdivisions opening up are housing younger couples. We are aware that approximately 1,000 people are arriving in south-east Queensland every week. They are coming from the southern states for one reason or another. It is because of my interest in aged care in particular that I wanted to make a contribution to this debate this morning.

I observe that this Main Committee is working pretty well. I think there were reservations on our side about it. Maybe there were even some reservations on the government side, but so far so good. The fact that we have the opportunity to speak to a report this morning indicates how useful this committee can be for that purpose. Reports are tabled in the House of Representatives which are very often important and comprehensive reports, such as this report, and they are the end result of hours and hours of deliberations. Those of us who have served on committees know just what sort of work is involved in putting together a report like this. It is a pity, when a report comes into the House of Representatives, if it is discussed for perhaps 30 or 40 minutes and that is it. This Main Committee will provide an opportunity to give more attention to these sorts of matters, and I believe that is very important.

In fact, members generally need to be aware that this committee gives us the same opportunity to express points of view as we have in the House of Representatives. Although the surroundings are far removed physically, and in terms of the furniture and so on, nevertheless, the impact is there and we can address these issues.

In that context, I wanted to make a few remarks about this report. I hasten to add that I was not a member of this committee; therefore, I am by no means familiar with the detail of it. When one serves on a committee that brings down a report such as this, obviously one lives and breathes it to a point where one really gets to know the particular subject very well. That is a benefit of being a member of a parliamentary committee. I have served on committees with the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) and I know that he and I agree that it gives an opportunity really to get a grip on a particular subject and to develop some expertise. Some bipartisanship generally results from that as well, because it becomes fairly obvious, when dealing with problems, that the solutions are very much in evidence and it is difficult to disagree about them. So there is a great benefit in that. I congratulate the chairman of the committee, who is here this morning, for the work that has gone into this report on what is, indeed, a very important area.

One of the key objectives of HACC services is to ensure that those services optimise the opportunity for people to remain home, supported by services that are responsive to individual needs. I happen to subscribe very strongly to the view—and I am sure that members of the committee agree with this—that it is good for people to be able to remain in their homes for as long as possible. We are not only talking about aged people but also talking about younger handicapped people. Most aged and handicapped people would prefer to remain in their homes. I am sure that the committee was confronted with plenty of evidence of that. Many of us have aged relatives. My mother will be turning 80 next year and she prefers to remain in her own home. Many of us with elderly relatives will experience the difficulty of actually convincing aged parents or relatives when the time comes that they can no longer take care of themselves. HACC services support people who make those choices and I believe that they are choices that people in our society want to make and indeed ought to be able to make.

I believe that the other important thing is that providing these services and financing these services simply makes good economic sense. I do not know where the cut-off point is in economic terms but I imagine that, for a long time, it is very much cheaper to provide these services for people in their homes than it is to provide hostel and nursing home places. I assume that that is the modus operandi. However, there comes a point when people cannot be adequately served and looked after in their homes. Of course, then we need to have an adequate supply of nursing home beds.

I raise this as a concern, and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) may want to comment in his summing-up, if he can. I am very concerned about the shortage of nursing home beds. I make this comment in the context of my own electorate, where we have 23 nursing homes and 18 hostels. That is a considerable number and it obviously reflects the fact, as I said earlier, that we have a very large number of retired and aged people. But there are still just not enough nursing home beds.

I wrote to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) about this problem recently, bringing to her attention the chronic shortage of nursing home beds on the Gold Coast and the fact that there is now a real crisis, with most nursing homes having long waiting lists. In preparing to make representations to the minister, I actually had meetings with a number of the nursing home directors of nursing on the Gold Coast. They explained quite clearly to me just how big the problem actually was. It has reached rather alarming proportions.

One particular nursing home director, in her discussions with me, said that she got 10 to 15 applications for residency each week, and that she had a vacancy only when somebody unfortunately died, which happened only twice per month, approximately. Obviously, if you work those statistics out, you will find just how long the waiting list for this particular nursing home was. When I checked around, I found that that was typical of nursing home waiting lists on the Gold Coast.

The people who had been assessed through the process as being suitable for nursing home beds were the people on the waiting lists. By implication they therefore needed to be receiving whatever level of care they had been designated as suitable for. These were people who were adjudged to be no longer capable of taking care of themselves in their own homes, despite the availability of the range of HACC services there.

I was pleased to receive a letter back from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health, in which he indicated that the south coast Queensland region had been identified by the department as an area of high growth for aged care accommodation, and that advertisements had been placed in the local press last year inviting expressions of interest in providing aged care accommodation and specifically identifying the region as a priority area for the provision of hostel and nursing home beds. I was pleased to read that, although essentially the question I had asked—how this situation had ever occurred—remained unanswered.

It was fairly obvious to anyone with any knowledge of the area that we were experiencing a shortage of nursing home beds and that we would continue to do so. It only needed somebody to be planning adequately for that not to have occurred. It is fine now for us to hear from the government, `Yes, we are aware of the problem; we are doing something about it,' but it is putting the cart in front of the horse to have left it so long. Because there is a considerable lead time in the construction of nursing homes and hostels, the problem will remain.

We get all sorts of input in our electorate offices, depending on where they are, but in my particular electorate hardly a week goes by when I do not get somebody contacting me to say, `I cannot get my mother into a nursing home or a hostel. She is at home. She falls over, and she lies on the floor for some hours before Meals on Wheels arrives.' These are serious problems; yet we are in many respects still only reacting too late to actually meet the particular need that exists.

I put those comments on record in the context of this debate, which is about providing services for people in their homes. The preference of the people concerned, and certainly in economic terms, is for them to stay at home. But we need to recognise that in some electorates, such as mine, there is a crying need for the next step in care for people, and that is care in an institution. In any case, we need to recognise that there comes a point when care at home is no longer adequate for people.

The frail aged need to be able to move smoothly into that next step of institutionalised care of some sort. There should not be the major disruption and trauma that occur when a couple get to the point of having to face the problem with an aged or invalid parent, or other relative, at home, and not knowing what to do about it, and not being able to get the person into a nursing home or hostel or whatever the accommodation might be.

The services provided by HACC—home nursing, home help, Meals on Wheels, community transport and a range of others—generally assist people to remain in their homes for as long as possible. They also assist carers of people with chronic illnesses such as dementia, which is becoming an increasing problem in our community, particularly as the community ages. Dementia appears to be a product of age in most cases and, as our community ages, dementia will become an increasing problem.

The aspect of HACC services I bring to the attention of the parliament and the parliamentary secretary is some confusion in my mind about the relationship between Commonwealth and state funding. It seems to me that there is a real weakness in the system in Queensland because, although in 1993 the Commonwealth government was offering to increase funding, as I understood it, that required the Queensland government to actually accept its responsibility to match that funding. What I found was happening with HACC services on the Gold Coast was that, although the offer from the Commonwealth was there, the Queensland government was not prepared to accept its particular responsibility and so, believe it or not, the offer of Commonwealth funds was not actually being taken up.

I wrote to the Queensland Minister for Health, Mr Hayward, about that, expressing my concerns that that was a fact. I do not know whether the committee actually addresses that issue in particular, but I want to put on record my concern that the system, as it is constructed, will not work unless the state government concerned is sensible enough to realise that it cannot look a gift horse in the mouth. That appears to me to be what had happened in Queensland with the growth funding that was provided by the Commonwealth not being matched by the Queensland state government.

Two particular matters in the report are very commendable. One is the recognition of the particular problem of access to services by younger people with disabilities. This is a particular group that the committee found was being overlooked. Most of the remarks in the context of this debate are addressed to the needs of older people and that is where no doubt the great majority of the services are directed. But I was pleased that the committee recommended that the Commonwealth, states and territories investigate fully as a matter of urgency the reasons for low levels of access to HACC services by younger people with disabilities and that they develop approaches to service delivery to address those causes.

The other one I was pleased to see was that the committee had addressed the problem of access by veterans and war widows. I applaud the recommendation it has made that access also be provided to veterans and war widows without discrimination. In general, I really appreciate the work this committee has done and I make my remarks in that context. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), I was not a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs that put this report Home but not alone together but, as the representative in this parliament of an electorate that has an extremely large percentage of ageing people and is a large consumer of the sorts of services provided under the HACC group, I thought it would be important that I make a few comments on it.

PARA.TAB: It was interesting listening to the member for McPherson describing the demographics in his electorate. It sounds very much like my electorate of Lyne. Lyne is another electorate on the mid-north coast of New South Wales which is experiencing a major growth in population of people who are moving into the area to retire, which likewise increases the demands and the pressure for the types of services that are provided under the HACC program. There already has been increased demand for nursing home and hostel accommodation, which is probably what we are trying to address in a lot of the areas that this report has covered.

I acknowledge and commend the staff of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs who worked with the committee members in this inquiry and in drafting this report. I think it is important that we acknowledge good work where it is being done. This is a majority report, and I think there is always going to be bipartisan support for the sort of work that is being done by the parliament in trying to improve and upgrade the services to that section of the community that we are focusing on here.

The need for these programs is increasing. Again talking a little parochially, in my electorate I have the areas of Forster, Tuncurry, Taree and Port Macquarie. Over the years there has been a great migration of retired people into those areas. People are being attracted by specific developments such as retirement villages and complexes where there are self-care units, with marginal nursing services being provided in extreme cases; but there are not the follow-on services as far as hostel accommodation and nursing home accommodation is concerned. That problem has always been there, but it is increasing.

The problem has not been identified just in my electorate, it is there in a lot of the electorates to which a lot of people are retiring: the population is ageing. Retired people are living longer, and they are living in these circumstances, but now we are getting to a stage where people are having to move back into the cities to find nursing home care. Along with the member for McPherson, I have constituent inquiries about this at least on a weekly basis, if not a daily basis. I hear from family members whose mother, father, brother or sister has been assessed as needing nursing home care, but to get that nursing home care they have had to move out of the electorate to Newcastle or Sydney—out of the area and away from close family—to be able to receive that care.

Budgetary considerations are always going to restrict the ability of governments, whatever their political persuasion, to be able to provide nursing home care. I recognise that once the government allocates a nursing home bed it then has to provide the recurrent funding to provide the service. Although in the target area of the Great Lakes there is the possibility of 31 beds coming up, it certainly does not do much to service the need: that is in excess of about 150 in my electorate at the moment. We have got to look at how we are going to provide the services and how we are going to look after these people in their homes, but we also have to recognise the work that the carers and volunteers do, and try to offer support to them.

On that aspect, I might just comment about the Meals on Wheels service in New South Wales. I am not exactly sure how things have changed, but I have had a lot of representation lately from volunteers who provide that Meals on Wheels service. I believe it is the New South Wales government that has put into place paid coordinators to restructure the service that is provided by Meals on Wheels. A lot of the volunteers are very possessive of the service that they provide. They are very proud of the service they provide through the Meals on Wheels service, and they have not appreciated the intervention of what I suppose to be the New South Wales health department.

I recently went to the annual general meeting and luncheon of the Forster-Tuncurry group that provide meals on wheels. They have remained an independent and autonomous group, just operating of their own accord, charging a minimal amount for their Meals on Wheels service. They have their own cars, and they have their own kitchen that has been provided within the Great Lakes Shire Council building complex at Forster. They have a full contingent of volunteers who prepare the meals and deliver the meals. They charge at a minimal rate, they do their little bit of fundraising, and they negotiate the cost of the merchandise they buy around the local community to provide those meals. The community is well served by a group of people made up entirely of volunteers.

This needs to be borne in mind by government. Government should recognise—and I think it has been identified in the report—that government cannot ever replace the amount of work or the type of care that is provided by the many thousands of volunteers and carers across Australia. What we have got to do is offer support to those people with the services that are provided. We have to make sure the infrastructure is in place and the policies are in place to do that.

An important part of the whole process of the provision of these services is to provide the backup, the support and the framework for the volunteers and carers to work under. A number of the previous speakers have spoken about the need for respite for carers, not just those caring for the aged but also those caring for people with disabilities. Their families who are caring for them in the home certainly do need the understanding and attention of different provider groups as far as respite is concerned. They are there and they are providing the service 24 hours a day. A lot of paid health and community workers might work an eight-hour shift, they might work a 10-hour shift, but then they step away from it. They are not in that situation after that whereas family and volunteer carers are in that situation 24 hours a day. It is certainly very onerous.

As far as some of the recommendations in the report are concerned, I want to touch on one particular area that was of interest to me and that is chapter 6, which deals with access by special needs groups. I want to comment on some of the recommendations which I support which make reference to remote, rural and isolated people. Obviously, people probably would not call my electorate remote or isolated. It is mostly a rural area with large pockets of population on the coast. When talking about equality of services between the metropolitan and regional areas of Australia, it is important to note that this is being recognised in this report as well. These are some of the recommendations that the committee has made:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Department of Human Services and Health work with States and Territories to develop and implement nationally consistent definitions of the terms rural, remote and isolated.

This is so there are not any groups in the community which are actually discriminated against. People who live in rural and remote areas should get equality of services as far as the type of service and the breadth of services that are provided go. The ultimate cost of the service is to the taxpayer. The recommendations continue:

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Department of Human Services and Health, in conjunction with the States and Territories, investigate the effectiveness of various approaches to service delivery in rural areas and, particularly, in remote and isolated areas and develop a rural and remote areas policy which encourages the funding of flexible approaches to service delivery including multiple service outlets with flexibility in the allocation of funds between service types. The policy must address the particular needs of remote and isolated areas.

The Committee recommends that guidelines for these projects in rural, remote and isolated areas take account of the particular needs of these areas and allow greater flexibility in terms of target groups and that staffing levels for the projects recognise the greater demands involved in remote and isolated areas where there are few established services.
The last recommendation in that section states:

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Department of Human Services and Health in consultation with the States and Territories investigate the additional costs of providing community care services in rural, remote and isolated areas in order to develop funding models for these areas which recognise any additional costs identified.

That is a very important element of the report. The House really needs to take note of that. In dealing with this report and in responding to it, the government needs to take note of that last recommendation. We must recognise the special needs in rural, remote and isolated areas; we must recognise that there are going to be additional costs in providing the services in those areas but, if we are to maintain a population in Australia that is spread across large distances in the very diverse nation that we are, we have got to be prepared to provide these services and to fund them in that way.

PARA.TAB: I commend the committee for that particular recommendation. It is terribly important that we do that. We should not forget people who suffer peculiar or different hardships from people in different areas such as my electorate just because they live where they live. They are trying to provide income for Australia and they want to stay in those areas because they are nearer to their families and they are in the environment that they are used to and that they feel comfortable in. Once again, I commend the committee for that recommendation. I also encourage the government, when responding to this report, to take particular notice of that aspect that has been raised by the committee.

In chapter 7 of the report, a couple of recommendations are made with regard to improving continuity between health and community care. Sometimes it is like the Commonwealth-state arrangements, where there seems to be a bit of a gap in communication. I note that the committee recommends that post-acute palliative care and rehabilitation in the community be funded from the health budget. Palliative care is an incredibly important aspect of the services provided. In my electorate, the base hospital in Port Macquarie is developing a rather large oncology unit and we have a large palliative care program going in the Hastings area and also in the Manning.

With the assistance of the member for Paterson (Mr Horne), who is a member of the government, we discussed with the then health minister, Senator Richardson, the ongoing funding of the palliative care program in the Manning area, which also covers Taree, Forster, Tuncurry, Bulahdelah as the Gloucester area, which are in the member for Paterson's area. The government provided that funding, which I think was over a five-year period, and that is going to mean the maintenance of a very important program in our area.

With a little more persuasion, we managed to get ongoing funding for the palliative care program that is provided in the Hastings area, again through the then health minister, Senator Richardson. That is certainly appreciated in the area as, because of the demography, the age of the population, and the location of the oncology unit at Port Macquarie base hospital, there is a great demand for the palliative care program. I have personal experience as far as the carers and the volunteers are concerned, because my father, who is a retired pharmacist, has just been through the training course to work in that palliative care program with sufferers. I commend the committee for that recommendation.
Chapter 10 of the report is about service delivery and costs. There is a recommendation there that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Commonwealth Department of Human Services and Health investigate any legislative barriers to the participation of the private sector in the provision of HACC services and work with States, Territories, local government, providers and consumers to develop a coherent policy to enable for-profit providers to seek funding to provide HACC services. This recommendation is conditional upon an examination of the relative efficiency of these services and the implementation of recommendations regarding mandatory service standards, external complaints mechanisms and accountability for outcomes and outputs.

I commend the committee on that particular recommendation. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) and the government generally to seriously consider that, because it seems that that is also a direction that, not just on a partisan basis, governments across Australia are taking in providing these services. We have to look at that aspect of providing these services to ensure that we can continue providing the services in the areas that are needed and to the people who need the services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to address the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs, entitled Home but not alone, which reports on its inquiry into the home and community care program. The committee has travelled and consulted widely, with a number of public hearings, forums and inspections being held across the country. As the committee chair, the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), has already stated, there is an overwhelming push from the community for continued involvement in the home and community care program, which I wholeheartedly support.

PARA.TAB: As the state and territory governments are also involved in the HACC program, services vary from state to state. In the case of New South Wales, the dual funding process has presented a particular set of problems. The HACC program, I believe, to date has proved to be very successful, although there is room for improvement and streamlining, particularly in the administration of the program's funding.

While the report makes many recommendations, there are three key points: regionalisation of the program; a single access point to the HACC program; and the shift of post-acute and palliative care. The report identifies the target group as people of all ages in the community with functional disabilities and carers. The recognition of this group represents a starting point for the implementation of changes to the HACC program.

There is a fine line between service delivery and cost effectiveness. Service delivery and cost effectiveness are not entirely incompatible, as many people would have us believe. Reducing the quality or irregularity of services does not mean increased cost effectiveness, and vice versa. The focus of the HACC program in this report must continue to be people driven, and not be merely an exercise in making the program more cost effective to the taxpayer.

It is important that the meaning and significance of this report's title is not lost during the debate and in the future. While it sounds like a take-off of a Hollywood blockbuster about a young boy left at home during Christmas, Home but not alone really does describe the motivation behind the program. In recent years, the government has continued to increase funding to the home and community care program, offering people an alternative to moving away from their homes in areas many people have been associated with for many years. Honourable members from both sides of the House will agree when I say that it is far better for people, whether they are young or old, to be assisted to stay in their own homes than to be placed in nursing homes, hostels or any other form of institution.

Home but not alone means exactly that. People, whether they are carers or are being cared for, are not alone. There is support for them, which may come in the form of such HACC services as home care or Meals on Wheels. The home and community care program is designed to complement the daily lives of people who are in need of assistance. I support this report, having been involved with many HACC funded organisations in my electorate of Richmond.

My electorate on the north coast, extending from Ballina in the south to Tweed Heads in the north, is one of the fastest growing electorates in New South Wales according to the 1991 census. The north coast urban planning report, released last year, estimates that within 20 years almost 20 per cent of the region will be over the age of 65. The region is a popular destination for retirees and that, along with migration and reduced mortality rates, accounts for the high proportion of the over-65 age group. The region has the highest proportion of elderly people in the state so, understandably, there is a great demand for services provided by the home and community care program.

There are a number of HACC services in the electorate, with Meals on Wheels, home care and respite services operating in Tweed Heads, Kingscliff, Murwillumbah, Brunswick Heads, Byron Bay and Ballina. Many of these services are run by volunteers. They deliver meals and provide services such as home maintenance to people who are unable to prepare their meals or keep up with the upkeep of their homes and gardens. Not only do these people provide much needed services, but they also provide a smile and some company on a regular basis to people who may not be mobile, or may not have friends and relatives close by. Next Wednesday I will join the Tweed Heads Meals on Wheels and deliver meals to celebrate national Meals on Wheels Day. I hope other members in this House will take the time to do that as well.

While these services receive funding through the home and community care program, a number of problems arose last year as the New South Wales government refused to match the Commonwealth's offer of growth funds. These cutbacks resulted in a reduction of services to many people who had been receiving assistance for a number of years and were suddenly cut off as services could be delivered only to the most needy.

Tweed Shire Home Care was one organisation that had to reduce its services this year because of a lack of funding. It provides assistance at home to people who are frail and aged, and younger people with disabilities. Services provided by Tweed Shire Home Care include housework, personal care, respite care, shopping, overnight care and a handyperson. The service provides assistance to over 440 people per month but it has been forced to reduce its customer numbers by 100 because of budgetary restraints. The home maintenance program has also suffered this year as it no longer has the resources to provide the handyperson service. A letter from Tweed Shire Home Care to a HACC public meeting held in June stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Until adequate funding is provided to this high growth area the gaps in service will continue to grow and the needs of this ageing community will not be met.

One home care volunteer from Tweed Heads commented to me recently that there is no point in assisting a person with meals and palliative care if there is no-one to look after the house or garden. How true these comments were. It is imperative that a full range of services is available or the objectives of the program can never be met.

PARA.TAB: The administration of the program has been a point of much frustration and concern within my electorate. I take the example of the Brunswick Valley Meals on Wheels service which is under the leadership of Mrs Gai Laverty, who has done an excellent job under difficult conditions. It is now operating out of the new Brunswick Valley community centre, which was substantially funded by the federal government. When that centre opened, the Brunswick Heads and Mullumbimby Meals on Wheels organisations amalgamated to form the Brunswick Valley Meals on Wheels Service. Prior to the completion of the community centre, with its very large kitchen, the meals came from the Mullumbimby hospital. In late 1992—and I emphasise 1992—it received approval to change to program funding and to employ a food services officer to run the service, which now provides up to 100 meals per day. It has only in the last four months received that funding to employ a food services officer to run the service.

I might reply to the comments on this of the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), who indicated his slight lack of knowledge of how the program is actually funded. In New South Wales the Department of Community Services is actually the provider of the service on the ground, with federal government funds. It was that change in management, if you like, which took so long for the New South Wales government to implement, which meant that it took more than 18 months for the simple change to program funding for the Brunswick Valley Meals on Wheels service to take effect and for it to employ a service officer to run that service.

For the last year the Brunswick Valley Meals on Wheels service has managed wholly and solely on the generosity and commitment of its committee and community volunteers. I would like to pay tribute to those people today for sticking to their guns during that period of time. I am not necessarily trying to point the finger at or lay the blame on either the state or federal government; I am merely highlighting the possibility of lengthy delays, which I hope will be avoided, for the recommended regionalisation of the program.

To be successful, the program must be fully integrated. Regionalisation of the HACC program would virtually ensure that people requiring assistance did not fall victims to political decisions but were assessed on their individual situations. Local professionals would be able to assess local people and make decisions about funding priorities in their particular region. The best placed people to make decisions about their local community, I believe, are the people who live and work in these communities.

A single access point to the multifaceted program, described in the report as the regional community assessment agency, will make the process easier for clients of the HACC services. The establishment of such an agency has the potential to offer clients of the home and community care program a one-stop shop for people requiring assistance through the program. The agency would ensure that appropriately trained people carry out the various assessment stages, which would depend on the individual circumstances and needs.

The crucial litmus test for the program will be the implementation of the recommendations on the ground. It is imperative that the administration and funding of the home and community care program reflect the needs of the program's client base. I commend this report to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Bevis) adjourned.
Consideration resumed from 8 June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEVIS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Grain Legumes Levy Amendment Bill is to ensure that grain legumes used by a producer on-farm for commercial purposes are not exempt for the purpose of research levy payment. Under the present Grain Legumes Levy Act 1985, producers are exempt from paying levy where the total levy payable is less than the leviable amount for that levy year and where the grain was processed by the producer and used on-farm for domestic purposes.

PARA.TAB: The Grains Council of Australia, which is the representative organisation under the legislation, is concerned to ensure that the exemption for grain legumes `used on-farm for domestic purposes' does not include, for example, a grain legume producer who establishes an intensive animal production unit on-farm and sources his stockfeed requirements internally. Consistent with the legislation applying to other grains under the Wheat Industry Fund Levy Act 1989 and the Coarse Grains Levy Act 1992, the amendment clarifies that such commercial operations carried out on-farm are liable for levy payment and facilitates levy collection and administrative arrangements.

The amendment will have no impact on levy collections or the budget additional to those already prescribed by the act. The act will commence on the day on which it receives the royal assent. I commend the bill to honourable members.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the spirit of bipartisanship, the previous speaker, the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), and I determined, in the absence of the last speaker on the previous bill, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell), that, in view of that amazingly colourful tie featuring sunflowers, he ought to be speaking on the Grain Legumes Levy Amendment Bill as well. I really do not know where he got the tie. He will be making the Speaker in the main chamber feel dispossessed if he keeps that up.

PARA.TAB: We support the Grain Legumes Levy Amendment Bill 1994. The bill will ensure that grain legumes and oilseeds used by producers on-farm for commercial purposes are subject to research levy payment. By way of background, the Grains Council, which is the representative organisation under the legislation for these grains, wants to ensure that the current exemption for grain legumes used on-farm for domestic purposes does not include producers who use them for intensive animal units involving, for example, pigs, cattle or chickens.

This action will bring these grains into line with other grains under the Wheat Industry Fund Levy Act 1989 and the Coarse Grains Levy Act 1992. Levies from legumes are expected to be down this year. Official estimates are that, because of the drought, the fall-off will be from around $4 million last year to $3.3 million this year. My suspicion is that the outcome will be significantly worse than that, given the fact that the drought is expanding at a truly alarming rate. We have the situation where 83 per cent of New South Wales is drought declared.

The legumes on which levies are paid are: field peas, lupins, faba beans, chick peas, mung beans, pigeon peas, peanuts, native beans, vetch, cow peas, and lentils. These crops not only are used domestically but also earn valuable export dollars for Australia. The value of the lupin crop in 1993-94 was estimated at about $255 million and exports were around $100 million in value. The value of the field pea crop is around $128 million and exports of peas, including field peas, chick peas and cow peas, are worth more than $150 million a year.

Research and development in the area of grain legumes is urgently needed in Australia because, in terms of the need to move towards sustainable production in agriculture, legumes have a major role to play. There are two essential problems. The first problem is the development of suitable varieties, and that includes the issues of disease resistance, insect resistance, yield performance and those sorts of things. The second problem is the one of finding further market outlets for commercially saleable grain legumes. Further market outlets are necessary in order to make the cost of sowing these crops a more attractive proposition, in terms of being able to offset them by returns, given that many farmers out there are struggling to find effective rotations for cereal crops. Legumes are vitally needed as part of that process, but often they are expensive to grow and it is very hard to achieve a return on them.

That brings me to the final point that I want to make this morning. The major environmental issue confronting this nation remains that of land and soil degradation. The key to sustainable land use is, of course, to some extent tied up with the whole philosophy and cultural change that landcare embodies, but landcare is running into some major problems. One problem is the rather bureaucratic nature of the animal as we know it today. The other problem is that, in the end, the capacity of farmers to look after their land, to put right past mistakes and to move to ecologically sustainable production in the future, is fundamentally and primarily impacted upon by their financial viability.

The No. 1 need for landcare—in other words, the No. 1 need when it comes to grappling with the environmental problems we have in this country—is to return farmers to profitability. That is, in fact, one of the reasons why the current extraordinarily serious drought across much of eastern Australia needs to be much more adequately addressed than it is being addressed at the moment by the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the previous speaker, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), I was attracted to the tie of the member for Richmond (Mr Newell), but he assures me that it is not oilseed sunflowers on it but Van Gogh sunflowers. That is probably why he is not participating in the debate on this bill.

PARA.TAB: The Grain Legumes Levy Amendment Bill could be described as an afterthought. It is the government's response to the fears expressed by the Grain Council of Australia that sections of the original bill, which this bill seeks to amend, allowed people who are using legume grain on-farm for domestic purposes to escape any levy. This bill puts beyond doubt that people who use the legumes on-farm for intensive agriculture, intensive animal production, will pay the levy but it still allows people to retain a small amount of seed for domestic purposes without attracting the levy. The amendment is good in that it puts that beyond doubt.

This levy, which is an ad valorem tax levied at one per cent of the net gate value paid to the farmer, goes to the Grains Research and Development Corporation research fund. It is matched by the Commonwealth government grant of up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of the commodity value of that particular crop. This figure is apparently arrived at by ABARE advice to the government.

The levy is applied principally to lupin and chickpeas but also to peanuts, lentils, soya beans, field peas and native beans. In passing, I might say that it is just as well it is not applied to has-beens, as it would put substantial costs on organisations such as the NFF.

Although I support this bill, the Grains Council should be aware of the fact that the tax, being a net tax on the farm gate, is a gross tax on the commodity, and one per cent on net value at the farm gate is probably between three or five per cent of the net value of the crop to the farmer. If that is allowed to rise, it could become quite significant, and I think that is something that the council will have to take into account. If it is allowed to rise too much, it will lead to substitution in some areas although the scope for that is not great. But in areas where substitution is available we might see people going into crops such as lucerne, tagasastes or even Maireana brevifolia, a native Australian plant which has not had much promotion in Australia but is being worked on extensively in South Africa. In South Africa it is often used as a high protein plant and irrigated in competition with some of these other alternatives.

It does seem to me that while the levy is at one per cent there is not going to be any trouble. Research into lupins, particularly—I single out lupins because I think this is the major crop—such things as mosaic, its effect on animal fertility, development of cultivars suitable for heavy soils, and other aspects of R&D which are well worth pursuing have the capacity to give a good return to the grower.

Indeed, while the lupin crop was worth over $250 million last year, I believe that it has potential for exponential growth in value. Lupins, probably more than any other crop, have a significant part to play in crop rotations and in the fixing of atmospheric nitrogen into the soil by virtue of the symbiotic relation to the rhizobia in their roots. Lupins have the capacity to grow on some very infertile ground, and peat sands are their preferred environment. There are not a lot of other plants that grow as well in these areas and, for this reason, lupins are of considerable value.

It is hard to speak at any length on a bill as basic as this, which is mainly a machinery bill to amend a perceived loophole, but I would like to say that rural Australia generally has a very important part to play in Australia. We have seen it being played down quite often today. In the areas of CSIRO research we are told that crops in rural Australia are being overfunded. I do not believe that this is the case at all. If one looks at the funding of CSIRO, a lot of the 40 per cent of funding that goes to the rural sector is in fact for downstream processing, which would be counted by other agencies as manufacturing and not as agriculture.

We have a serious drought in eastern Australia. I must say that I am very lucky that I come from Western Australia where we never have droughts. I do, however, recall that we had 10 crop failures in 11 successive years without attracting the same attention that the eastern states get. However, in the west we get used to that, and I guess that is what makes Western Australia the premium lupin state and the leading innovator in agriculture in this nation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Bevis)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.
Consideration resumed from 8 June.
