SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe The Hon N.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Oilseeds Levy Amendment Bill is to ensure that oilseeds used by a producer on-farm for commercial purposes are not exempt for the purposes of research levy payment. Under the present Oilseeds Levy Act 1977, producers are exempt from paying levy where the total levy payable is less than the leviable amount for that levy year and where the seed was processed by the producer and used on-farm for domestic purposes.

PARA.TAB: The Grains Council of Australia, which is the representative organisation under the legislation, is concerned to ensure that the exemption for oilseeds used on farm for domestic purposes does not include, for example, an oilseed producer who establishes an intensive animal production unit on-farm and sources his stockfeed requirements internally.

Consistent with the legislation applying to other grains under the Wheat Industry Fund Levy Act 1989 and the Coarse Grains Levy Act 1992, the amendment clarifies that such commercial operations carried out on-farm are liable for levy payment and facilitates levy collection and administrative arrangements. The amendment will have no impact on levy collections or the budget additional to those already prescribed by the act. The act will commence on the day on which it receives the royal assent. I commend the bill to honourable members.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We support the Oilseeds Levy Amendment Bill 1994. The bill will ensure that oilseeds used by a producer on-farm for commercial purposes are subject to research levy payment. The Grains Council of Australia, as I said in relation to the earlier bill, the Grain Legumes Levy Amendment Bill, is the representative organisation under the legislation for these grains and it wants to ensure that the current exemption for oilseeds used on-farm for domestic purposes does not include a producer who uses them for an intensive animal unit—pigs, cattle, chickens, or whatever—on a farm or, alternatively, sets up a manufacturing industry, for example a margarine plant, to gain an unfair advantage. This will bring oilseeds into line with other grains under the Wheat Industry Fund Levy Act 1989 and the Coarse Grains Levy Act 1992.

PARA.TAB: Oilseed production in Australia is expanding and, as people look for alternative crops and as markets expand—for example, in 1991-92 only 84,000 tonnes of sunflower seed were produced and last year that rose to 176,000 tonnes—it will be interesting to see what happens if the drought breaks in eastern Australia this year. I suspect that there will be a dramatic increase in the sowings of summer crops, and if it breaks soon enough that may include sunflowers. Research and development levies are expected to amount to just over $2 million in this financial year and are paid on the following oilseeds: sunflowers, soya beans, linseed, safflower and rapeseed. The coalition supports this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to rise in support of the Oilseeds Levy Amendment Bill this morning. This is the appropriate place as it is a non-contentious issue and we have the agreement of the opposition on this bill. Although it is a widely held view, especially in media reports, that there is a lot of disagreement in parliament, most primary industry legislation goes through with agreement, and I know the government makes an effort to consult with the opposition on these matters.

PARA.TAB: The Oilseeds Levy Amendment Bill 1994 has the majority support of the industry and the Grains Council of Australia. It is aimed at ensuring that all the producers of reasonable quantities of oilseeds and all those who use the oil for commercial profit pay the levy. There were anomalies in the previous act and that meant that some producers, who may have been using oilseeds for other areas of commercial operations, could avoid paying the levies.

It meant that these producers of commercial quantities of oilseed could have gained the benefits of the industry and government funded research and development of oilseeds, without contributing in a proper way to the research and development costs. It meant that they were gaining the benefits of research into crop development without cost. It meant that other producers who were paying their levies were paying for more than their fair share. So this bill is really about improving the equity of the oilseed levy collection. It is about ensuring that those producers who gain an economic benefit from the research and development of oilseeds pay their way. I do not think there is any scope for argument against that rationale of the bill.

When presented with bills of this nature, I am sure it is important that the intended consequences of the legislation are borne out. I note that some other legislation along these lines, the Cattle Transaction Levy Act, was brought in in 1990. That was brought in supposedly to gain greater equity through the industry. It had the support of the Cattlemens Union and the Cattle Council, and it gained the support of the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Kerin.

The industry had argued, and I think reasonably, that the levy collection system prior to that—the slaughter levy—was unjust. It was argued that, in many areas, producers were escaping payment of the levy because they reared cattle, sold them and never actually sent them along to slaughter. That argument was sound. It was simple. It was unfair that the only person paying the levy was the last person to own the beast.

The industry came up with the new proposal, the Cattle Transaction Levy Act, and it suited many people. But, on the north coast of New South Wales, the inequities were still there. The producers there, many of whom had previously escaped the slaughter levy, were, and continue to be, put at a disadvantage because of the new levy. My electorate covers an area where cattle change hands a number of times. It is not uncommon for a beast to change hands three or four times. That means that the flat rate levy has a greater impact in an electorate like mine. When the levy was originally introduced, it was set at a level of about $6 a transaction. If the beast changed hands four times, it meant that a beast returned a total levy of close to $24.

In other inland areas, notably western Queensland, the beast often attracted the once only transaction levy of $6. Despite arguments to the contrary, it meant the producers in my own area were having to cut their profits per head to match other producers who, by simple fortune of location, had their cattle change hands only once.

The situation has changed a bit now, because the levy has been cut down quite a degree, but I think the disadvantage is still there. I see that there are still inequities in the transaction levy which we need to avoid whenever we are devising new levy systems. It is important, in discussing these levies, that there has been proper consultation with the industry as a whole, and I think that case bears that out, because inequity is still there, which the transaction levy was supposed to address.

Last week I wrote to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Bob Collins, suggesting that consideration be given to altering the system of levies for cattle involved in home slaughter. My attention was drawn to this after being approached by a constituent who had been out of work for a couple of years. He had been a butcher and he had been helped to gain work through the CES and the new enterprise incentive scheme. He had started his own business to get off the jobsearch allowance and he was butchering beasts on the property of the owner, but he has been told by the AMLC that a levy is payable when the beast is slaughtered.

I wrote to the department saying that there should not be a payment due because the beast had not changed hands. I was told that the levy should only be applicable once for each owner, but in the same letter the department countered its own argument by saying that the person performing the home slaughter should charge the transaction levy to the owner of the beast. That argument seems pretty hollow to me. In almost every instance the owner will already have paid the levy when the beast was purchased and is now being forced to pay it again during slaughter. I believe that an ad valorem system would have been much fairer and involves very little extra effort in collection.

The point is that, when we are considering changing levy systems, we need to be very much aware that the changes are going to increase fairness and equity to all producers. I think that neither the slaughter levy nor the transaction levy is really fair. I am satisfied, however, that the bill we are considering this morning does meet that equity criterion. It brings the levy system for oilseeds into line with levies covering the wheat industry and the coarse grains industry.

The summary of the legislation provided to the government and the opposition says that the Oilseeds Levy Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 provides for amendments to the Oilseeds Levy Act 1977 to ensure that oilseeds used by a producer on-farm for commercial purposes are not exempt for the purpose of research levy payment. The amendment is being made at the request of the Grains Council of Australia, the representative organisation under the act. The council did make it clear to me that it was fully supportive of the bill and its passage through the parliament.

The Grains Council has asked the parliament to support changes to the act in the past, most recently in 1992, when the levy system was changed from a specific rate per tonne to an ad valorem system to improve its equity. At that time the request also received bipartisan support. I think it is incumbent on the parliament to ensure that this equity based amendment also receives quick but considered passage.

Oilseeds include sunflower seed, safflower seed, soya beans, rapeseed, cotton seed and linseed, which are mainly grown for their oil content. The main areas of oilseed cultivation are the central highlands of Queensland, western Victoria, the south-east of South Australia and the New South Wales north coast. On the north coast of New South Wales, soya bean is the main crop used in oilseed production. A report from the New South Wales Department of Agriculture in 1991 detailed quite extensive research on soya bean development. This is the type of research that the levies we are discussing this morning would go to fund. Soya bean variety trials have been conducted each season at several localities on different soil types in coastal soya bean growing areas. Growing conditions and soil types in most of the coastal regions were shown to be conducive to high yields.

The research shows that varieties with strong tolerance to excess manganese and probably tolerance to delayed harvest weathering and sclerotinia provided the best results. Further tests showed that the post-maturity weathering has caused serious losses in growing yield and quality in most soya bean producing areas of both New South Wales and Queensland. It found varieties which were less susceptible to rain-induced late harvesting, most notably dune.

The point in mentioning this is that research of this type will produce results which will be applicable to all soya bean growers. It is imperative then that all commercial producers who gain the benefits from this type of research do contribute to the funding. That is why this bill has important ramifications and I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be reported to the House without amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe The Hon N.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I just need some assistance with the word `triticale'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what it is.
—I assume it is a form of grain.
—It is a cross between rye and barley.

—I have spent half of my life in the country and I have never heard of it! The purpose of the Coarse Grains Levy Amendment Bill 1994 is to change the basis on which research levies for barley and triticale are paid from a specific rate per tonne to an ad valorem rate. At present, the Coarse Grains Levy Act 1992 provides for the imposition of levies on oats, cereal rye, sorghum, millet, maize and canary seed at ad valorem rates, and barley and triticale at specific rates per tonne, as recommended by the Grains Council of Australia (GCA) and, in the case of triticale, the Triticale Grain Association of Australia (TGAA), which are the representative organisations under the act.

PARA.TAB: These levies can be increased by regulation up to a maximum rate also specified in the act. The levy rates for barley and triticale are currently $1.10 per tonne and $1 per tonne respectively. The levies attract matching Commonwealth contributions as provided for under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989.

The change is being implemented at the request of the GCA, with the agreement of the TGAA with regard to triticale, and is intended to make the payment arrangements more equitable. The ad valorem levies proposed would ensure that growers' contributions to research are proportional to their net returns from the relevant crop. In other words, the amount of levy payable in dollar terms will be directly linked to the grower's capacity to pay.

The change will standardise payment arrangements for all coarse grains and also bring them into line with other grain research levies applying to wheat, oilseeds, seeds and grain legumes which are all levied on an ad valorem basis. The GCA and TGAA have recommended an initial operative levy rate of one per cent of the net farm gate value and a maximum rate of five per cent for both barley and triticale.

In line with the change from a specific rate to an ad valorem basis, any exemptions applying will now be expressed in value terms and all references to leviable weight have been omitted from the legislation. The change to ad valorem based levies is not expected to result in any significant change in the Commonwealth's dollar-for-dollar matching contributions in relation to barley and triticale as current specific levy rates were set at the equivalent of one per cent of net farm gate value.

It is intended that the new levy basis will take effect on 1 October this year, if possible, to coincide with the commencement of the first quarterly collection period of the new crop year for barley and triticale. If the amending legislation is not effective by that date, it will not commence until 1 October 1995, to avoid changing the levy arrangements during a crop year.

The opportunity is also being taken to effect a minor drafting amendment to the legislation which will avoid confusion that has been occurring amongst some levy payers regarding their liabilities in respect of oats and rye harvested prior to 1 October 1992 but delivered or processed after that date. I commend the bill to honourable members.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief, because again we support this legislation. The Coarse Grains Levy Amendment Bill 1994 seems to me to be one of those clean-up actions that one of the previous speakers on the other side made reference to. Essentially it changes the basis for assessing research levies on barley and triticale from a flat rate per tonne to an ad valorem rate, which brings the arrangements for these products into line with oats, cereal rye, sorghum, maize, millet and canary seed. It is appropriate that this be done, it is fair that it be done, and therefore we support it.

PARA.TAB: The Grains Council of Australia and the Triticale Grain Association of New South Wales have recommended the change as a fairer system which would ensure that growers' contributions to research are proportional to their net returns from the relevant crop instead of being a flat rate regardless of the price received. Both organisations have recommended an initial operative levy rate of one per cent of net farm gate value, and there is a maximum rate in the legislation of five per cent. It should be noted that this is five per cent of the net farm gate value. It should not be confused with the 0.5 per cent of the gross value of the product, which is the maximum amount for dollar for dollar funding for the government research and development funding arrangements.

Those research and development funding arrangements enjoy very strong bipartisan support in this place, and it is really quite interesting to come up into this place—as contrasted with our other place—where we can agree on almost everything in primary industry. We will go back down there to argue on some of the areas where we have major disagreements, but I have been interested to note here the comments about the importance of the rural sector of the Australian economy. Barley is a contributor to that. Production in 1993-94 was valued at $925 million, exports at $464 million. Exports of barley this year will have fallen through the floor. They will be absolutely minuscule.

The eastern drought is a severe drought, no ordinary drought, and we need to draw that distinction. We need to highlight the unbelievable effect that drought is having on production based primary industry, which has already been hit very hard by the unbelievably difficult economic circumstances that agriculture faced in the 1980s. Now, in many instances—consider, for example, the Darling Downs—some of the most productive agricultural land in Australia is devastated. In some instances farmers there have lost up to eight crops in a row. I heard the other day of one individual who had 100 per cent equity in his farm four years ago, but is now down to 40 per cent. He has not had a crop now for four years. He is basically finished unless a responsible package can be put in place to ensure that when rain does come he has a means of clawing back his position, winding back that debt.

We are facing an extraordinarily serious problem. I understand that the total loss now to the Queensland economy alone is estimated at some $3.6 billion, and the loss to the New South Wales economy at about $1.5 billion. Again it is a huge figure, and it is set to get much worse if the drought continues to bite. Yesterday we saw the area covered by drought declarations increase to the point where 83 per cent of New South Wales is in drought. Not all of that is severe drought, but in areas it is a severe drought. It is a natural catastrophe of extraordinary proportions which is threatening entire rural communities. That, in turn, is threatening their capacity to contribute again to the nation's economic wellbeing and export performance, even when rain does come.

I think a very clear point needs to be made at this stage. There is an assumption that, when rains come, rural industries simply get going again. They plant crops somehow and they mysteriously restock their properties. I believe that there are huge numbers of farmers across this country who will simply not be in a position to do that when this drought breaks. Their financial position is so fragile, and the country is in such a mess, that it is just not going to happen. The potential downside for the nation is absolutely enormous.

Returning briefly to the bill, triticale is a cross between wheat and rye. It is used mainly for animal feed. We grew it for the first time in this country in the 1970s. I have looked at it; I have found it an interesting crop. It seems to perform better in slightly harder soils than we have at home. I would not say that it has become an enormously important crop in the overall Australian context. Nonetheless, it does have its place in the array of feed grains. In 1992-93, the crop was worth some $36 million, which I guess is not an insignificant amount.

Last year, levies from coarse grains raised just over $7 million. This money is being used to help Australian farmers stay ahead through excellent research work. That is very important and, as I indicated, it is an area where we do have strong bipartisan support for the arrangements in place. This is extremely significant in the sense that Australian agricultural production and performance has been to the forefront in this nation in terms of improving performance on a year by year basis. That effort can be maintained only if, on the one hand, farmers are viable and, on the other hand, scientific research effort is kept up.

The current levy on barley is $1.01 per tonne and on triticale it is $1. The new rate will be one per cent of the value of the grain. This amount can be altered by regulation up to a maximum rate of five per cent of sales value. I have no doubt that those organisations would never move to that sort of rate because their constituents would scream long and hard. I would make the observation that in one sense the timing is just a little unfortunate. The new rate of one per cent on barley this year is likely to mean that the rate will be significantly above what it was. Barley, for the first time in a few years, is likely to be worth significantly more this year than it was last year but farmers will not have very much of it. On that note, I conclude with the observation that we do support this bill as we supported the previous two. It is very nice to be able to join members on the other side on a bipartisan basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), has indicated, there is bipartisan support for this Coarse Grains Levy Amendment Bill as would be expected. By way of background, triticale is the name of a grain developed by crossing wheat and rye, as previous speakers have indicated. Significant commercial production of triticale commenced in the 1970s. The present uses for human consumption are: flakes for muesli; flour and wholegrains, especially in breads; and the manufacture of triticale macaroni. It has been claimed that triticale has an advantage over bread wheats in highland areas in acid soils and in areas where drought tolerance is needed. However, there is no evidence that triticale varieties in Australia survive drier conditions better than wheat or that they are resistant to stem rust. Varieties of triticale have been shown to do well in heavy and acid soils.

PARA.TAB: The levies imposed by the Coarse Grains Levy Act 1992 were imposed by the Commonwealth. It requested the coarse grains industry itself to match Commonwealth funds up to the maximum 0.5 per cent of the industry's gross value of production. The principal uses of the proceeds raised by the levies included funding research and development and health and safety. It is estimated that the receipts from the coarse grain levy will total $7.077 million and $6.602 million in 1994-95.

This legislation has bipartisan support. I follow the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir, and I find it a little bit unfortunate that he once again sought to use this occasion to criticise the government in relation to its drought policy. Drought is obviously something that is of great concern to rural areas in Australia. It is very fortunate that my electorate does not suffer that problem at the moment, but there are lots of areas in my state of Queensland as well as areas in New South Wales that are suffering.

It was very disappointing in the House yesterday when the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), set out the government's policy in relation to drought and set out the considerable amount of support that the government is providing, and the response from the coalition was, `Not enough, not enough'—a sort of mindless response.

The Commonwealth approach to drought is based on the national drought policy and its principles of sustainable development, risk management, productivity growth and structural adjustment in the farm sector. Consistent with the national drought policy, the Commonwealth has established a number of long-term measures to assist farmers to prepare for the risk of drought, including the national property management planning campaign, drought related research and development, the income equalisation deposit, farm management bond schemes and, very importantly, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be aware, the rural adjustment scheme. As you would know, the rural adjustment scheme has several legs.

The first I refer to is the exceptional circumstances provision which clearly comes into play in relation to drought. It is just very strange that the coalition would choose to criticise the government about RAS, because RAS has been around for a long time. I am not sure, but I think it was the Fraser government that brought in RAS. Certainly, it has been supported throughout by the Hawke and Keating governments. The exceptional circumstances provision of RAS allows for short-term target assistance to long-term profitable farmers to cover exceptional circumstances, such as drought, which cannot reasonably be expected to be taken into account.

As well as that, the government also provides assistance under the normal RAS to improve the productivity of enterprises when they can be shown to be profitable in the longer term, and for education and training to improve farm management skills and professional advice. In addition, re-establishment support of up to $45,000 may be available for those farmers whose long-term prospects are poor and who wish to leave farming. Farmers in need who wish to remain in farming but are unable to demonstrate that they can be profitable in the long term might be eligible for a jobsearch allowance or farm household support.

So there are three basic legs for farmers. If they are in a situation of short-term exceptional problems and they suffer drought, they have assistance through the exceptional circumstances leg. If they are in a normal situation and need structural adjustment, it is provided by RAS. Obviously, drought is a factor that cannot be discounted from that. If it is a factor, then they can also apply. With those farmers in really dire circumstances, in circumstances where it would not matter whether there was a drought or not, circumstances where one is talking about really marginal farms, I would have thought that there would be some bipartisan support there. That provision comes where people, unfortunately, mostly end up in the social security system under jobsearch or farm household support.

RAS is administered by the states in accordance with policy guidelines provided by the Commonwealth. In New South Wales, it is administered by the Rural Assistance Authority; in Queensland, by the QIDC. It is interesting that there has been some comment about the fact that, when looking at our six states, there are differences in terms of the outcome of RAS. Basically there are different authorities, so there is a different outcome in terms of lending. We hear the coalition time and time again talking about states rights, and this is an inevitable consequence of giving this up to the states. I think it is something the Commonwealth can look at, because there are very clear discrepancies between the different state authorities in terms of lending policies and RAS.

Nevertheless, that is something that should be worked out on a cooperative basis between the states and the Commonwealth; it is something we have to look at. If a farmer in Western Australia is eligible under RAS and somehow a farmer in New South Wales or Queensland is not, that is a problem. But I do not know how the coalition gets around it if it supports states rights.

The Commonwealth is also providing a network of rural financial counsellors who provide free and confidential financial advice to farmers. Normal social security benefits are also available to those in the rural community who are in financial difficulties. In response to the extended drought in Queensland and north-west New South Wales, the federal government has allocated $14 million in additional emergency financial assistance to drought affected primary producers in those states. This package includes the immediate provision of an additional $2.5 million in exceptional circumstances funds to Queensland, which I referred to earlier, and $5 million in exceptional circumstances funds to New South Wales. That continues until 31 December 1994.

The need for further funding beyond 1994 will be the subject of a review in November 1994, following the receipt of a report from the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council. We are not saying—and we have never said—that that is the end of drought assistance. RAS is an interest subsidy scheme and there is not a determinate figure. Obviously, there have to be continual reviews to make the scheme work, and that is sensible. So when coalition members interject in the chamber`Not enough' it reflects on them and not on the government. The allocations of Commonwealth expenditure that have been provided under RAS since September 1992 total $47.2 million—but the coalition says `Not enough'.

As well, a $5 million pilot extension will also be made to the training and skills enhancement task project in Queensland and New South Wales. This project is aimed at the development of the provision of training, including a wage subsidy for farm employees in drought affected areas, and it will assist in retaining farm management skills in rural areas. This government is concerned about farmers, but it is also concerned about farm workers. You do not hear the coalition talk very much about farm workers—

TALK.START.PARA: —Never.

—The honourable member for Lyons is probably correct in saying never. It is very unfortunate that because of technological change we have not got a lot of farm workers left in Australia. Twenty or 30 years ago in my electorate that would have been the major source of employment. Very few people are now in farm employment, but there are still some. Obviously our sympathy goes out to farmers, but another unfortunate effect of drought is that workers are put off, and the government is also concerned about that.

PARA.TAB: In addition, $1.39 million has been provided for the expansion of financial and family counselling services in drought affected areas, including provision for a communications program to improve awareness of assistance available to the farming community. This is very important, because drought has not only a financial impact but also a very strong emotional impact on families. Drought affects families, whether they are farmers or farm workers, and the government recognises that. The government has a very proud record in dealing with a very difficult problem.

The National Party seems to believe that buckets of money exist in government. When you are out of government for 11 years, you suddenly think that government has got this unlimited money pot. Obviously, our government would like to provide more, but, given the financial restraints on the government and its deficit reduction strategy, I think the Commonwealth government can stand proud for its response to the very difficult problem of drought. It reflects on the coalition that it would make the kinds of statements that were made in the House in question time yesterday and by the Deputy Leader of the National Party the honourable member for Gwydir, today.

In summary, I support this legislation. It is important that, although we deal with problems of drought, we still address the future of rural industry and questions such as research and development, because that is obviously the key. I said on a previous occasion that one of the reasons we have got a vital and vibrant rural industry in this country is that we have concentrated on research and development. That is something we can be proud of. This bill continues that tradition, and I support the legislation before this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate and to respond briefly to the remarks made by the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd). The bill before the Main Committee, which is the Coarse Grains Levy Amendment Bill, as other speakers have indicated, changes the basis for research levies on barley and triticale from a flat rate per tonne to an ad valorem rate. This will bring these products into line—as others are well aware and have indicated to the Main Committee—with oats, cereal, rye, sorghum, maize, millet and canary seed.

PARA.TAB: The Grains Council of Australia and the Triticale Grain Association of Australia have recommended the change as a fairer system which would ensure that growers' contributions to research are proportional to their net return from the relevant crop instead of being a flat rate, regardless of the price received. Both the Grains Council and the Triticale Grain Association have recommended an initial operative levy rate of one per cent of net farm gate value and a maximum rate in the legislation of five per cent.

Fundamentally, we are here in bipartisan support of this legislation because it offers farmers a fairer way of making a contribution to research. I note that all of the bills that have been dealt with before this Main Committee this morning—the Grain Legumes Levy Amendment Bill, the Oilseeds Levy Amendment Bill and this bill—have been supported because fundamentally they go about providing a fairer way of offering that collection of funds for research.

I do not wish to refer to those bills, as they have been passed in the chamber, but I think it is reasonable in the context of this bill to note that, whereas in the case of the Grain Legumes Levy Amendment Bill the arrangements fundamentally were to ensure that intensive industries were picked up and made a contribution but that the contribution was not made unfairly, the same sort of analogy can be applied to the bill currently before the committee. The purpose of the bill is to make the levy collection fundamentally fairer.

As all speakers have indicated, the state of affairs in rural Australia as of August-September 1994 is not pretty. As the member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) has indicated, 83 per cent of New South Wales has been declared drought stricken, and parts of northern New South Wales and much of Queensland are going into their third or fourth year of drought. That has some bearing on this legislation, because triticale was originally generated as a grain seed that was seen to be more drought resistant than wheat or barley. That has not proven in practice to be entirely the fact, but the reality is that triticale is now sown in a number of areas where some rotation is sought and where a level of drought resistance is needed in whatever grain is being used for research.

I am familiar with triticale—although not personally—because the farmers in my area, the Mallee area of South Australia, chose it as an alternative crop to wheat and barley in the early stages of triticale's development. As has been indicated in this chamber, the area currently sown to triticale runs at something like 120,000 hectares, generating about $36 million. While triticale is now principally used as a feed for pigs and poultry it also has, I have discovered, some application in the breakfast cereal industry and is used as flakes for muesli, and for flour and wholegrains in specialty breads.

Triticale has been developed as a grain to meet the unique nature of the Australian farming environment and the propensity that this country has for droughts. I also note that this bill has a particular emphasis, as the preceding bills to it have had, on research, because the levies being collected are being collected principally for research, especially into better ways to grow grains and legume crops.

I want to make a comment or two about research in Australia, and I am choosing to take remarks given by Mr Julian Cribb, who is known to all of us, and who delivered a speech at a rural crisis conference in Murray Bridge last week. About his concern for Australian research he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our task is to make Australia a world supplier of information about food, farming and environmental care—but first we have to get it right at home.
It will be necessary for farm organisations and local governments to supply much of the essential information their industries need—especially about markets, technology and business management.
We have an untapped treasurehouse of native Australian plant and animal species which we have virtually ignored as farm industries for the last 200 years.
To underline the national lack of interest in our biological resources, I note:
* the world's largest producers of Australia native wildflowers are Holland and Israel
* the world's largest eucalypt farmers are Brazil and China
* Portugal is the world's largest producer of eucalyptus oil, the Chileans are selling us blue gum described as `Chilean oak', and the Finns are selling gum trees to Africa
* Thailand is farming barramundi, mudcrabs and tiger prawns
* Africa, Israel and America are the biggest growers of our desert shrubs.
Mr Cribb continued:
These examples clearly show the opportunities which other, smarter, nations see in Australia's biological resources.

I am not standing here making a criticism of the government in that context. Rather, I indicate the need that we have as a nation to expand our research base, and acknowledge that the bills before the House this morning will allow us to do just that through the collection of additional research levies.

PARA.TAB: While the present picture of rural Australia may not be a pretty one because of the reality of drought that we cannot escape, on a decade by decade sequence, the other simple truth is that we know better than most of the world how to weather a drought. The need we have is for further research so that we can better face these sorts of difficulties and so that we can sell this sort of research to other countries, rather than having them exploited, as Mr Cribb has indicated.

I want to pick up a comment or two made by the honourable member for Leichhardt. I was a little surprised at the level of indignation that the member for Leichhardt expressed about what he saw as the coalition's reaction to the government's drought package. With respect, I suggest that were the roles reversed—I know that is almost beyond the imagination of those opposite—there would have been as much criticism levelled at the coalition in government if present government members were sitting in opposition and being lobbied by rural Australia.

I acknowledge the member for Leichhardt's comment about the drought package that the government has in place, but I put to honourable members that it is extraordinary for the member for Leichhardt to be indignant that any opposition should call out for more. As he himself said, `Quite obviously, we'—that is the government, I presume—`would like to provide more.' Quite obviously, we, as the opposition, have an obligation on behalf of all Australians to ask for more. That is not to say that nothing is happening, but in light of what is happening, and in light of the present level of the difficulties being faced by rural Australia, it is hardly surprising—there is hardly any call for apology on the part of the opposition—that it should be asking for a little more consideration. After all, those of us with rural electorates—on both sides of this chamber—represent areas that have seen farm debt go from something like $6 billion to $17 billion.

Our constituents—the people of the nation—spend, I am told, $10 billion every year chasing slow horses and dogs, and only $3 billion on the research that we need to expand Australia's technological base. The nation itself has not yet captured the need for research that we believe is so essential. But we face the simple reality that 200,000 farms existed in Australia a quarter of century ago, and that number has fallen to 110,000. Rural Australia, right now, is bearing the brunt of what has been a necessary readjustment initiated by the government and backed by the opposition, but it is carrying that brunt along with the burden of a drought. It is in that context that, without apology, the opposition said yesterday, `Thank you, but could we have some more?'

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Coarse Grains Levy Amendment Bill, about which the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) made some comments.

PARA.TAB: The readjustment which is taking place in rural Australia is also taking place in most work sites and manufacturing areas throughout this country. I know that in my area of Tasmania there are opportunities to be taken up when change is made, especially growing potatoes and other crops. These changes—and some are major changes—need to be faced by the farming community, even though changes are not always easy to face, and it is up to us within the parliament to make sure that we are positive about the changes. The rural sector has to change, in the same way as manufacturing and many other industries have to change.

The honourable member for Wakefield made a good contribution, especially in relation to research. I believe that research is the key to our future. Research and development was lagging far behind, but this government, over the last 10 years, has put it high on its agenda. The government has a great opportunity through the taxation system to support R&D, especially in the rural sector, and I believe that that opportunity is untapped. The honourable member put on the record a quote about some of the areas in which other countries have taken up native Australian plant and animal species and are utilising them industrially to great value for themselves.

This bill, of course, provides amendments to change the basis on which research levies are imposed. In this case it is in relation to barley and triticale, which I am not overfamiliar with. I am very familiar with barley, having sowed many a bag of barley on the family farm as a 13- or 14-year-old working on the header. Ours was basically a dairy farm, and we grew barley for feed in the piggery and in the dairy. I understand that triticale is a cross between wheat and rye. These days it is used as a feed grain for pigs and poultry; it is consumed as flakes in muesli; it is produced as wholegrain flour for specialty breads; and it is used in the manufacture of triticale macaroni. That must be interesting—I have never tasted triticale macaroni. There are a couple of other tastes that I will have to try. I am always interested in finding a new taste for my palate, and that sort of macaroni is one I will have to look out for.

The levy will go from a flat rate per tonne to an ad valorem rate in accordance with the value that is there. The levy will be based on the percentage value of this product, which is around one per cent of the net farm gate value. The levy revenue attracts matching Commonwealth contributions and it is used to fund research programs for these grains in the Grains Research and Development Corporation. This has all been done with the approval and the agreement of the growers through the Grains Council of Australia and, of course, the government talks to the industry that is involved. It is not expected to result in any significant change to the Commonwealth matching contributions dollar for dollar in relation to these grains, as current specific levy rates were set at the equivalent of one per cent per farm gate value, as I mentioned before.

The research into grains such as barley is particularly important to growers in Tasmania. Members may not be aware that Tasmania has always grown a lot of barley. The background to the industry starts with early settlement in Tasmania, and members would be well aware that Tasmania fed New South Wales for quite a long time. We are very keen to continue to remind people in New South Wales that they would probably have all died out if Tasmania had not been there to grow the grains to feed them. We fed them on grains such as wheat and barley. The wheat in Tasmania can never be grown as hard as it can be grown in mainland Australia, so our wheat is more often used in the biscuit manufacturing side of things, rather than in making a very sharp flour for breads.

In 1860 we were growing cereal crops over an area of about 26,000 hectares, producing about 38,500 tons. In 1993 the area was around 26,700 hectares, producing 67,000 tonnes, so we have increased our production per hectare considerably over that period. Today, barley is the main cereal crop, and production has been as high as 40,000 tonnes per year. Over 50 per cent of the cereal crop is produced in northern Tasmania, and a lot of that is grown in my electorate of Lyons. There has been a major expansion in barley production in recent years because of the Kirin brewery contract in Western Australia, and this led to the activities in the processing sector over the last two years.

Tasmanian breweries use about 6,000 tonnes of malting barley and this is likely to increase. For instance, in April of this year, a decision was made to reopen the barley malting plant in Devonport. This move will see the demand for locally produced Franklin malting barley increase from about 5,500 tonnes to more than 8,000 tonnes annually. These two breweries are now using the barley, and there is a likelihood of an expansion in this area because of the success of both the northern and southern Tasmanian beers, which are being exported all over the world. There is quite a competition between the north and the south these days. Mr Deputy Speaker, you may have tasted the two beers. They are being exported to the UK, the US, and now into China, I understand, so Tasmanian beers have an international reputation.

I understand that genetic stock from the very good Tasmanian malting variety Franklin is being used to assist in developing a new cool country barley for growing in other parts of Australia. It is a useful variety, because it requires a long growing season and it has resistance to barley yellow dwarf virus, which seems to be the major disease that affects barley. More research in these sorts of projects will certainly be very useful and, of course, can come from these types of levies. For instance, the high protein content in the Tasmanian barley this year, because of the unusual weather conditions, may have affected the state's exports. Apparently a high protein content in barley is not all that good when you get into beer making and brewing, and research into the quality control of protein levels would certainly assist the farmers in Tasmania. Alternatively, there may be other uses for this high protein material. For example, it can be used for malting for other uses than beer brewing, and in food additives, et cetera.

A number of major processors are specialising in feed for the expanding aquaculture industry. As you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, the aquaculture industry is an industry that has grown enormously in Tasmania in recent times, and barley is the basis for producing food for the salmon and trout industries.

There was an announcement from a New Zealand company about the latest dairying ventures, which will include a new herd in the north-west of the state. There is likely to be 1,400 milkers added to the expanding dairy industry in Tasmania. Barley has been used as an initial feed supplement and it could take part in this expansion. The dairy industry in Tasmania has a very bright and strong future.

Tasmanian feedlots, although not as big as mainland feedlots, would still provide a useful market and an outlet for some of the barley in the Tasmanian scene. Of course, there is the traditional barley use of the Irish—juice of the barley, Johnny Barleycorn, good old-fashioned whisky. Tasmania has some of the best water in the world, so why not convert some of that into making juice of the barley, as the Irish would say?

When I was in Scotland I visited a number of distilleries that used the Scottish mountain water, and I wondered why Tasmania was not producing some of the great highland dew that Scotland does. I heard only the other day—and I was reminded of my travels—that someone was starting up a distillery in Tasmania. I have not heard the details of that yet, but it has been on the drawing board for a short time. Hopefully, that will be another industry using barley coming out of Tasmania. If the Japanese can go close to reproducing an accepted whisky, I am sure that Tasmania could do likewise.

Legislation like this really assists in the research into the right sort of barley that we could use in that process to add another product to the state's exports and value adding. Barley growing could have a really good future in Tasmania, and our state government should recognise that there is a need for some infrastructure and support for it.

The farmers are reminded of how—when they received the contract to Western Australia in recent years—they were going to have great difficulty in loading their crop, because all we do in Tasmania is import. We import some wheat, and so we have the Grain Elevator Board, which is about taking grains out of ships; it is not about loading ships. So those farmers used their initiative and used one of the woodchip conveyor belts to load the ship with barley. Last year, to load their crop they actually developed that a bit further and put a hopper on the end of it so that they could blow it into the ship's hull.

The growers also bought and put together their own dryer so they could dry their crop to make it even better and value add to it. So they are doing a lot themselves to increase their opportunities. The state government, which is in charge of that sort of infrastructure, needs to look long and hard at the support that it is giving to the barley growers of Tasmania.

There is talk of the Grain Elevator Board being sold by the state government. I believe that would be a backward step. There is certainly a need for storage, loading and unloading facilities to assist the Tasmanian barley farmers. The state government is certainly not looking to do that in any positive way, but rather is going backwards in its thinking.

Some of the projects funded by the levy have assisted, I understand, the growing of faba beans as an alternative grain legume crop in serial rotations in the northern midlands of Tasmania, so another opportunity may exist there.

Another opportunity lies in getting the quality focus on the grain industry development program for Tasmania. It is the quality that we would be looking at achieving, and it is through these sorts of levies and the research they finance that we would be looking at making some gains.

There has been a study of the extension of minimum tillage practices—or none—for a cereal program. This, of course, would bring about enormous savings in diesel fuels and machinery. There is also the possibility of research into yellow dwarf viruses in winter cereals, especially oats, and it is really these levies which make this sort of research possible on an ongoing basis. There are lots of opportunities for research in the industry, and these research levies will become more and more important for keeping us competitive and for increasing exports from Tasmania, even to the mainland. I commend the bill to the committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mrs Crosio)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.
Motion (by Mrs Crosio) agreed to:
That order of the day No. 12 be returned to the House for further consideration:
Motion to take note of paper

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 31 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Prime Minister stated that racial vilification legislation which will include criminal sanctions will be introduced to the Parliament before the end of 1994.

(2) Has a report been prepared by officers of his Department who took submissions and held consultative meetings around Australia on a draft racial vilification bill; if so, will he release the report to the public; if not, why not.
(3) Did officers of his Department advise that criminal sanctions should not be included in a racial vilification bill.
(4) Will the racial vilification bill to be introduced include criminal sanctions.
(5) Is he representing the wishes of the majority of Australians in the matter of racial vilification legislation; if so, what is the evidence to support this.
(6) Will he state the precise time frame for the introduction of racial vilification legislation; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised that the answer is `no'.

(2) In my Ministerial capacity I have received a number of briefings from my Departmental advisers on proposed racial vilification legislation. I have also received reports from my Departmental advisers on the result of public consultations held early in 1993 which have been put to Cabinet and will not be released publicly.

(3) My Departmental advisers have put a number of options to me to consider in relation to racial vilification legislation. Their advice has canvassed all options, including the options of enacting and not enacting criminal sanctions.
(4) I am unable to answer this question pending Cabinet consideration of any proposed racial vilification legislation.

(5) As the Honourable Member will know, this issue has been considered and reported on in three reports to Government and extensive consultations were undertaken with the community by the bodies responsible for those reports, namely, the Australian Law Reform Commission, the Royal Commission Into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Whilst I am not able to say what the views of all Australians are on the issue, the Government must give weight to the recommendations of these reports.
(6) I am unable to answer this question pending Cabinet consideration of any proposed racial vilification legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 7 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a claim in the Canberra Times of 6 June 1994 that Australia is losing its native mammal species at a faster rate than is occurring anywhere else in the world.

(2) Is it a fact that (a) Australia has lost 20 native mammal species in 200 years while the rest of the world has lost 60 species in 500 years, (b) a further 123 species have been listed as endangered and (c) more species have become endangered since 1984 than in the preceding decade.
(3) What credentials does the Government claim in environmental management and what is the basis for those credentials.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes

(2)(a) Australia has lost 20 native mammal species in the last 200 years, which represents half the total lost in the world in that period. Reliable figures for losses over the last 500 years are not available.
(b) No, 30 native mammals are listed as endangered in the Commonwealth Endangered Species Protection Act 1992, not 123. A further 18 are listed as vulnerable.

(c) The first nationally agreed list of Australian endangered vertebrates was adopted in 1980. It is therefore not possible to indicate whether more species have become endangered since 1984 than in the preceding decade. However it is significant that population decline of many endangered species has been halted or reversed by the application of research results, and the implementation of conservation management.
(3) It is not clear what the honourable member means by "credentials . . . in environmental management".

The Commonwealth Government has significant responsibilities and powers in the area of the environment. The Commonwealth Government seeks to give effect to its environmental objectives and obligations through a number of laws and programs and through cooperative arrangements with the States and Territories and local Governments throughout Australia.

The Commonwealth has available to it significant environmental management expertise from within its own Departments and Agencies which is supplemented from time to time by the expertise of the Australian academic and professional communities. Australia is well regarded internationally for the range and depth of its environmental expertise.
